Dear Josephine,

During a tax audit, we were asked to justify the amounts paid to foreign service providers, as we had to pay retroactive withholding tax to the French tax authorities, in accordance with agreements between France and these countries. These amounts should be deducted from the amounts owed to these service providers. Consequently, their taxes will be deducted accordingly. However, if these service providers are up to date with their taxes in their country of residence, these withholdings will not be applied.
This is why we are asking you to send them to us, depending on your situation.
In your case, we need proof of taxes paid by the individual or legal entity that received ‚Ç¨1,800 in 2023.

 

Hope everything is clear to you, and please don't hesitate to contact us if you need anything. 

 

Thank you for your understanding of this tax process, which is beyond our control.

 

Best regards

Le jeu. 19 juin 2025 √† 16:42, Jos√©phine Lesaffre <josephinelesaffre@outlook.com> a √©crit :

Hello St√©phanie,

 

You have previously received from me the FORM 8802 for 2023 (see our previous emails attached).

Since our contract was indeed in 2023, I am curious why the forms of 2022 and 2024 are needed? 

 

Thank you in advance for clarifying üôÇ

Bets regards,

 

Jos√©phine Lesaffre

UX/UI Designer | Illustrator

07 52 67 47 24 

De : St√©phanie NGUYEN <stephanie.nguyen@learningplanetinstitute.org>
Envoy√© : vendredi 13 juin 2025 10:39
√Ä : josephinelesaffre@outlook.com <josephinelesaffre@outlook.com>
Cc : Marie Guiraud <marie.guiraud@learningplanetinstitute.org>; Finance LPI <finance@learningplanetinstitute.org>
Objet : FORM 8802

 

Dear Josephine,

Following up on our previous emails, we urgently need you to provide us the FORM 8802 for the period 2022-2023-2024 :

As part of international tax cooperation, treaties between countries determine how taxes should be calculated in France on amounts paid by French entities to service providers residing outside of France. the French Tax Administration will require us to withhold the maximum tax rate, i.e., 25% of the amounts paid by LPI, if we dont't have your certificate of tax residence (form 8802) completed by the US Tax Admnistration, we would have to charge this amount to you.
With this document, the tax rate may be reduced according to the applicable treaties, and you should be able to deduct these amounts from the taxes you paid in your country of residence.

We appreciate your prompt response and remain at your disposal for any further information.

Best regards,

St√©phanie]]]

Got it ‚Äî this makes sense now.  

When a **European company** pays money to a **foreign service provider** (like your U.S. company), they are sometimes legally required to withhold taxes *unless* the provider proves they are already a tax resident in their own country.  

üëâ The document they‚Äôre asking for is a **U.S. Tax Residency Certificate**.  
In the U.S., this is obtained by filing **IRS Form 8802 (Application for U.S. Residency Certification)**. When approved, the IRS issues **Form 6166**, which is the official *Certificate of U.S. Tax Residence*.  

### What it is:
- **Form 6166** is a letter from the IRS confirming that your company (Nur Creative Studio) is a tax resident of the United States for a specific year.  
- It is used under **double tax treaties** so that the French entity does not withhold extra French taxes on top of the U.S. taxes you already owe.  

### Why they need it:
- France (and most EU countries) has tax treaties with the U.S.  
- Without this certificate, the French company is legally obligated to withhold up to **25%** of the payment they made to you.  
- With the certificate, they can justify to their tax auditors that you‚Äôre a U.S. tax resident, so they don‚Äôt need to withhold French tax.  

### What you need to do:
1. **Apply to the IRS with Form 8802** (you can do this online or by mail).  
   - There is a processing fee (around $85).  
   - You need your company‚Äôs EIN and proof you filed U.S. taxes.  
2. The IRS will send you **Form 6166** (the actual residency certificate).  
3. Send the Form 6166 to the French company ‚Äî that‚Äôs what they‚Äôre asking for.  

‚ö†Ô∏è Important: **Your 1040 or 1120 tax return, or a CPA letter, is not enough.** The French tax authority only accepts the official IRS certificate (Form 6166).  

---

Would you like me to **draft a short reply email** you could send back to them, explaining that in the U.S. the certificate is Form 6166 (requested via Form 8802) and that you‚Äôre applying for it now?
i am an LLC in america, do i still need to do this?

Yes ‚Äî being an **LLC in America** doesn‚Äôt change the French side‚Äôs requirement.  

The French accountants aren‚Äôt asking whether you filed taxes ‚Äî they need **proof from the IRS** that your entity is officially treated as a **U.S. tax resident** under the U.S.‚ÄìFrance tax treaty.  

Here‚Äôs how it works for LLCs:

- **Single-member LLC (disregarded entity)** ‚Üí By default, the IRS treats it as part of your personal taxes (Schedule C on your 1040).  
  - In this case, *you personally* would apply for Form 8802 using your **SSN**, and the IRS would issue **Form 6166 in your name**.  
- **Multi-member LLC (partnership)** ‚Üí The LLC files Form 1065. The IRS can still issue Form 6166 in the LLC‚Äôs name, but you need the LLC‚Äôs EIN.  
- **LLC taxed as a corporation (you filed Form 8832 or 2553)** ‚Üí The LLC is its own taxpayer, so Form 6166 will be issued to the LLC.  

üëâ In all cases, **yes, you need to request Form 6166** (via Form 8802), but whether it‚Äôs in your **name** or the **LLC‚Äôs name** depends on your tax classification.  

---

‚úÖ So the practical next step:  
- Check how your LLC is taxed (disregarded, partnership, or corporation).  
- File **Form 8802** with the IRS.  
- Get **Form 6166** back.  
- Send it to the French company so they don‚Äôt withhold 25% of your payment.  

---

Do you want me to break down *step-by-step* what to file for each LLC type (single-member, multi-member, or corporation)? That way you‚Äôll know exactly which path applies to you.

when i get the 6166 is there anything else i need to do? I'm a tiny LLC and i had one contract for 1000 dollars with a french school and they're asking me for this. I don't get it and know if i need to do it

That‚Äôs a totally fair reaction ‚Äî for a **$1,000 contract**, this feels like overkill üòÖ. But from the French school‚Äôs perspective, their **auditors** are forcing them to collect this, or else they have to withhold French taxes.  

Here‚Äôs the **practical reality for you as a small U.S. LLC**:  

---

### 1. What the French school needs
- They need **official proof from the IRS** that you are a U.S. tax resident (so they don‚Äôt withhold 25%).  
- That proof = **Form 6166** (Certificate of U.S. Tax Residence), which you request by filing **Form 8802**.  

---

### 2. If you do get Form 6166
- You just **send them the PDF/letter** from the IRS.  
- You don‚Äôt need to file anything else in France.  
- You still report the $1,000 income on your normal U.S. tax return (Schedule C, Form 1065, or 1120 depending on how your LLC is taxed).  
- That‚Äôs it ‚Äî no extra U.S. filings just because of France.  

---

### 3. If you don‚Äôt get Form 6166
- The French school might be legally forced to **withhold ~25% (‚Ç¨250)** from what they paid you.  
- They would pay that to the French tax office, and you‚Äôd only get the remainder.  
- You *could* try to claim that back later using the U.S.‚ÄìFrance tax treaty, but that process is very bureaucratic and not worth it for $250.  

---

### 4. The ‚Äútiny LLC‚Äù question  
For just **one $1,000 contract**, you need to weigh:  

- **Cost/effort of Form 8802**: $85 IRS fee + paperwork, takes weeks/months.  
- **Potential withholding**: ~‚Ç¨250 lost.  
- If this is a **one-off**, honestly, it may not be worth filing 8802/6166. You might just accept the withholding.  
- If you plan to do **more French/EU contracts**, it‚Äôs worth setting this up once so you have the certificate ready.  

---

üëâ Bottom line:  
- If it‚Äôs just this $1,000: it may be cheaper to **let them withhold** than to go through the IRS process.  
- If you expect more EU clients: **apply for Form 6166 once**, then reuse it for all of them in the same year.  

---

Do you want me to **draft you a short reply** you can send the French school explaining that you‚Äôre a small U.S. LLC, this is one $1,000 contract, and asking whether they really need the IRS certificate or if they can just withhold the treaty rate? That could save you the headache.
once i get it do i use it forever?

Unfortunately, no ‚Äî you can‚Äôt use it forever.  

üëâ **Form 6166 (the IRS Certificate of U.S. Tax Residence)** is only valid for **the calendar year** it covers.  

- If you request it for 2023, it only certifies that you (or your LLC) were a U.S. tax resident in 2023.  
- If in 2024 a French (or German, Dutch, etc.) client asks again, you‚Äôd need to apply for another 6166 for 2024.  

Some points:  
- You can request it **retroactively** (for past years) or **in advance** (for the current year).  
- You can request **multiple copies** with one Form 8802 submission if you expect to need it for several clients.  
- Once you have it for the year, you can **reuse the same certificate with as many European clients as you want**.  

---

‚úÖ So it‚Äôs not a ‚Äúone and done forever‚Äù document, but it *is* reusable across all contracts in that tax year.  

---

Do you want me to show you how a small LLC like yours can **minimize the hassle and cost** (for example: applying once a year, asking for multiple copies, and wording the application to cover both you personally and the LLC if needed)?
can i get them to ship it to me overseas in france?

Yes ‚Äî the IRS **will mail Form 6166 internationally**.  

Here‚Äôs how it works:  

- On **Form 8802**, there‚Äôs a space to list the address where the IRS should send the certificate. You can put your French address there.  
- The IRS mails Form 6166 as a **paper letter on official IRS letterhead** ‚Äî no PDF by email.  
- They do ship abroad, but international mail can take weeks.  

üëâ Tips to make it smoother:  
- If you‚Äôre in France for a while, just put your **French mailing address** on the 8802.  
- If you‚Äôre moving around or worried about delays, you could list a **trusted U.S. mailing address** (friend, family, or registered agent). Then have them scan and forward it to you.  
- You can also request **multiple originals** on Form 8802 (at no extra cost) ‚Äî useful if you need to send them to more than one client.  

---

‚ö†Ô∏è The IRS is very old-school about this. No email. No download. Only snail mail.  

---

Would you like me to draft a quick step-by-step of how to fill out **Form 8802** for your exact situation (tiny U.S. LLC, living in France, one client), so you don‚Äôt overcomplicate it?

here's my LLC info, what is it, and how do I fill the 8802?: '''DEPARTMENT OF THE TREASURY

Perfect, thanks for sharing that notice ‚Äî it tells us a lot about your LLC. Let‚Äôs break it down.  

---

### 1. What your IRS notice says about **Nur Creative Studio LLC**  
- EIN: **81-4514826**  
- Entity type: **LLC**  
- IRS expected you to file **Form 1065 (partnership return)** ‚Äî meaning they treated your LLC as a **multi-member partnership** when you applied.  
- Member listed: **Bilal S Ghalib**  

‚ö†Ô∏è If you are the **only member**, the IRS may have expected you to elect single-member treatment (disregarded entity, reported on your 1040 Schedule C). But since they sent you a 1065 notice, they may have you flagged as a **partnership**.  
üëâ If in reality you‚Äôre single-member and have been filing as such, that‚Äôs fine ‚Äî but for Form 8802/6166, it matters which classification you‚Äôve been filing under.  

---

### 2. How this affects **Form 8802 (Application for U.S. Residency Certification)**  
Form 8802 is the application. The IRS will then issue **Form 6166**, the certificate.  

**Key parts you‚Äôll fill out (simplified for your case):**

- **Line 1 ‚Äì Applicant name**:  
  ‚Üí *NUR CREATIVE STUDIO LLC*  

- **Line 2 ‚Äì EIN**:  
  ‚Üí *81-4514826*  

- **Line 3 ‚Äì Address**:  
  ‚Üí If you‚Äôre in France, put your French address here. That‚Äôs where the IRS will mail the certificate.  

- **Line 4 ‚Äì Type of entity**:  
  ‚Üí LLC (taxed as **partnership** if you filed 1065, or as **disregarded entity** if you report on your 1040 Schedule C).  

- **Line 5 ‚Äì U.S. income tax return filed**:  
  ‚Üí If single-member: *1040 with Schedule C*.  
  ‚Üí If multi-member: *1065*.  
  ‚Üí If you elected corporate status: *1120*.  

- **Line 7 ‚Äì Calendar year(s) requested**:  
  ‚Üí Put **2023** (since that‚Äôs what the French school wants). You can also request 2024 at the same time if you expect more contracts.  

- **Line 8 ‚Äì Treaty country**:  
  ‚Üí France  

- **Signature**:  
  ‚Üí Signed by you as the member/manager.  

---

### 3. Fee & submission
- Fee: **$85** (per application, not per certificate).  
- Payment: Use IRS pay.gov (recommended).  
- Mailing: You send the 8802 to the IRS in Philadelphia. They process and mail Form 6166 back.  

---

### 4. What you do with the 6166  
- When you receive it, **send a copy to the French school**.  
- That‚Äôs it ‚Äî no extra filing with France.  
- You keep reporting the $1,000 income normally on your U.S. tax return.  

---

‚úÖ So, for you:  
- **If you file Schedule C (single-member)** ‚Üí you request Form 6166 in your **own name** (Bilal Ghalib), referencing your LLC/EIN.  
- **If you file Form 1065 (partnership)** ‚Üí you request it in the **LLC‚Äôs name**.  

---

Do you want me to **mock-fill Form 8802** for you (with dummy address details for now) so you can see exactly what it would look like for Nur Creative Studio?
ok, well, I guess we have this LLC as a partnership, I filled it out with ym cousin to begin, and I'm the only one doing things

Got it ‚Äî that clears things up.  

Since the IRS initially classified **Nur Creative Studio LLC** as a **partnership** (because you had at least two members when you applied for the EIN), that means:  

- Unless you later filed **Form 8832 (entity classification election)** or **Form 1065** with ‚Äúfinal return,‚Äù the IRS still expects your LLC to be a **partnership**.  
- Even if your cousin isn‚Äôt active anymore, the IRS will still consider it a partnership until you formally change it.  

üëâ For **Form 8802**, you should therefore apply **as a partnership** (the LLC itself is the applicant, not you personally).  

---

### How that looks on Form 8802 (your case)

- **Line 1** (Applicant name):  
  `NUR CREATIVE STUDIO LLC`  

- **Line 2** (EIN):  
  `81-4514826`  

- **Line 3** (Address):  
  Your current French address (so the IRS mails Form 6166 directly to you).  

- **Line 4** (Type of entity):  
  `Partnership`  

- **Line 5** (U.S. tax return filed):  
  `Form 1065` (U.S. Return of Partnership Income)  

- **Line 7** (Calendar year(s)):  
  `2023` (and you can also request `2024` while you‚Äôre at it).  

- **Line 8** (Treaty country):  
  `France`  

- **Signature**:  
  You, as the managing member of the LLC.  

---

### What happens next
1. File Form 8802 (+ $85 fee).  
2. Wait for IRS to process and mail you **Form 6166**.  
3. Send the Form 6166 to the French school.  
4. Done ‚Äî no other U.S. or French filing needed.  

---

‚ö†Ô∏è One thing: If you‚Äôve actually been reporting your LLC income on **your personal return (Schedule C)** instead of Form 1065, then the IRS records and your filings don‚Äôt match. In that case, applying as a **partnership** may cause confusion later.  

Would you like me to help you figure out whether the IRS ‚Äúsees‚Äù your LLC as an active **partnership** or as a **disregarded entity** right now? That way you‚Äôll know which version of the 8802 is safest to file.
ok, let's apply as a partnership, does that change how we do the taxes? I've been filing the LLC with my individual return is that a problem?

Ah, here‚Äôs the important bit.  

Right now, you have a **mismatch** between what the IRS expects and what you‚Äôve been filing:  

---

### 1. How the IRS views your LLC (based on your EIN notice)
- You applied for your EIN with **two members** (you and your cousin).  
- The IRS classified you as a **partnership** ‚Üí they expect you to file **Form 1065** every year.  

---

### 2. How you‚Äôve been filing
- You‚Äôve been reporting the LLC‚Äôs income directly on your **personal return (Schedule C on Form 1040)**.  
- That‚Äôs what you‚Äôd do if the LLC were a **single-member disregarded entity**.  

---

### 3. Why this is a problem
- If the IRS still considers you a partnership, **filing only on your personal return is technically incorrect**.  
- Partnerships must file a **1065** return and issue a **K-1** to each partner.  
- Not filing Form 1065 can trigger penalties (though if the LLC really has only one active member now, you may be able to fix it).  

---

### 4. What this means for Form 8802
- If you apply as a **partnership** but haven‚Äôt been filing 1065s, the IRS may reject your application because it won‚Äôt match their records.  
- If you apply as a **disregarded entity (Schedule C)**, but their records still list you as a partnership, they may also reject it.  

---

### 5. What you can do
You have two paths:  

**Option A ‚Äì Clean it up as a partnership (conservative IRS approach):**  
- File any missing **1065s** (even if late).  
- Issue a final 1065 marking the year your cousin stopped being a member.

That‚Äôs actually a very common situation ‚Äî lots of small partnerships/LLCs lose money or barely make anything. The IRS still expects a return, even if there‚Äôs **zero income**.  

Here‚Äôs how it works for a **partnership LLC filing Form 1065**:  

---

### 1. Form 1065 basics
- **Form 1065** is the U.S. Return of Partnership Income.  
- It shows the partnership‚Äôs total income, deductions, and expenses.  
- The partnership itself usually pays **no federal income tax** ‚Äî instead, it ‚Äúpasses through‚Äù the results to the partners.  

---

### 2. When you make no money or lose money
- You still file Form 1065.  
- Report the income = $0 (or whatever tiny revenue).  
- Report the expenses (hosting, software, travel, etc.).  
- The **net loss** flows through to you (and your cousin, if still listed as a member).  

That loss gets reported on **Schedule K-1**, which the partnership must issue to each partner.  
- K-1s show each partner‚Äôs share of income/loss.  
- You (and your cousin, if still on record) attach the K-1 to your personal 1040.  

---

### 3. Why this matters
- Filing a **1065** even with losses keeps you compliant with the IRS.  
- If you don‚Äôt file, the IRS can hit the LLC with penalties: **$220 per partner, per month, up to 12 months** (so if they still think it‚Äôs a 2-member LLC, that‚Äôs $440/month until it‚Äôs filed).  

---

### 4. If your cousin isn‚Äôt really active anymore
- You can file one last 1065 as a **‚ÄúFinal Return‚Äù** marking the year your cousin left (put ‚ÄúFinal return‚Äù at the top and check the box on Form 1065).  
- Then going forward, you‚Äôre a **single-member LLC**, and you can just report on **Schedule C** with your personal 1040. No more 1065.  
- That would also make your future **Form 8802 applications** much simpler.  

---

### 5. Your next step
If you haven‚Äôt filed any 1065s yet, you‚Äôve technically been out of compliance since 2017. But the IRS is often lenient with **small, no-income partnerships** if you voluntarily fix it. You‚Äôd basically:  
- File retroactive 1065s (even with $0 income).  
- Mark the current one as **final**.  
- Switch to Schedule C from now on.  

---

üëâ So to answer your question:  
- **Yes, you must file 1065 even if the partnership loses money.**  
- The losses can actually help you reduce your personal taxable income (they flow through to your 1040).

Great questions ‚Äî let‚Äôs break this down step by step:  

---

### 1. What a **disregarded entity** means
- An LLC can be taxed in different ways (partnership, corporation, disregarded).  
- A **disregarded entity** = the IRS ignores the LLC for tax purposes.  
- All the business‚Äôs income/loss ‚Äúflows through‚Äù to you personally and gets reported on your **Form 1040 (with Schedule C)**.  
- The LLC still exists legally for contracts, liability, and branding, but for taxes it‚Äôs just *you*.  

That‚Äôs exactly what you‚Äôre doing now (your Schedule C shows ‚ÄúNur Creative Studio‚Äù).  

---

### 2. Does your U.S. tax return show tax residency?
- Your **Form 1040 + Schedule C** proves that you file U.S. taxes as a resident.  
- But: foreign tax authorities (like France) **don‚Äôt accept** your 1040 or CPA letters as official ‚Äúresidency proof.‚Äù  
- They only recognize the **IRS-issued Form 6166 (Certificate of U.S. Tax Residency)**.  

---

### 3. Do you need the Tax Residency Certificate?
- **Yes, if the French school insists on it.**  
- They‚Äôre audited under French law: if they don‚Äôt have Form 6166 from you, they must withhold ~25% of your pay.  
- If they get the certificate, they can show their auditors that you‚Äôre a U.S. taxpayer, so they don‚Äôt need to withhold.  

üëâ So: your U.S. tax return shows you are a resident, but **only Form 6166 counts as the official certificate** that France will accept.  

---

‚úÖ Summary:  
- You are a **disregarded entity (sole proprietor)**.  
- Your **1040 proves residency in substance**, but **France requires Form 6166 from the IRS**.  
- So yes, you still need to apply for the Tax Residency Certificate (Form 8802 ‚Üí IRS ‚Üí Form 6166).

what does it mean to be a us tax resident then, and does that mean because of the tax treaties I don't need to pay french taxes either?

This is a really good and important question. Let‚Äôs separate **U.S. tax residency** from **French tax residency** and then see how the treaties fit in:  

---

### 1. **What it means to be a U.S. tax resident**
- For the IRS, if you are a **U.S. citizen** (which you are), you are always a **U.S. tax resident** ‚Äî even if you live abroad the whole year.  
- That means you are required to file a **Form 1040** every year, reporting *worldwide income*.  
- You can then reduce or eliminate U.S. tax by using tools like:  
  - **Foreign Earned Income Exclusion (Form 2555)**  
  - **Foreign Tax Credit (Form 1116)**  

üëâ So being a U.S. citizen = automatic U.S. tax resident. It‚Äôs about filing obligations, not where you live.  

---

### 2. **French tax residency**
France looks at different rules. You may be considered French tax resident if you:  
- Live in France more than **183 days per year**, OR  
- Your **household/family** is based in France, OR  
- Your **main professional activity** is in France, OR  
- Your **center of economic interests** is in France.  

If one of these applies, France can also claim you as a French tax resident.  

---

### 3. **What happens if both countries claim you**
That‚Äôs where the **U.S.‚ÄìFrance tax treaty** comes in.  
- The treaty has **‚Äútie-breaker rules‚Äù** to decide which country has the first right to tax your income.  
- Generally, if you live and work in France, France will have **primary taxing rights** on that income.  
- The U.S. still makes you file a 1040, but you can exclude that income (Form 2555) or claim French taxes paid as a credit (Form 1116), so you don‚Äôt get taxed twice.  

---

### 4. **For your situation (2023)**
- You filed a **1040** ‚Üí you are a U.S. tax resident.  
- You also lived in France all year ‚Üí France could also see you as a French tax resident.  
- The treaty avoids **double taxation**:  
  - If France taxes your local income, you don‚Äôt have to pay full U.S. tax on it.  
  - If the U.S. taxes it, you can deduct French taxes paid.  

üëâ The French school is asking for **Form 6166** only to prove to the French tax authorities that you are a U.S. tax resident. That way, *they* don‚Äôt have to withhold French tax on the money they paid you.  

---

‚úÖ Summary:  
- Being a **U.S. tax resident** = you must file a 1040 and report worldwide income, no matter where you live.  
- Living in France makes you potentially a **French tax resident** too, but the **treaty prevents double taxation**.  
- The certificate (Form 6166) doesn‚Äôt exempt you from French taxes personally ‚Äî it just prevents the **French payer (the school)** from withholding tax from your invoice.
